[paragraph]III <u>Mathematical Theory of Newtons diagram of Colours<\u>
<s>Newtons diagram is a plane figure so coloured that 
the resultant of mixing the colours of two given points in any 
proportion is the colour of a point between them determined 
by cutting the line joining the two points inversely as the 
intensities of the <s>two colo<\s> compound colours<\s>
Newtons diagram is a plane figure, designed to exhibit 
the relations of colours to each other. 
Every point in the diagram represents a colour, simple 
or compound, and we may conceive the diagram itself so 
painted, that every colour is found at its corresponding point. 
Any colour, differing only in quantity of illumination from one 
of the colours of the diagram, is referred to it as a unit, and is 
measured by the ratio of the illumination of the given colour to that of the corresponding 
colour in the diagram. In this way the <u>quantity<\u> of a colour is estimated. 
The resultant of mixing any two colours of the diagram is found 
by dividing the line joining them inversely as the quantity of each, 
then, if the sum of these quantities is unity, the <s>point so found<\s> resultant will 
have the <s>intensity<\s> illumination as well as the colour of the point so found, but 
if the sum of the components is different from unity, the <u>quantity<\u> of the 
resultant will be measured by the sum of the components. 
This method of determining the position of the resultant colour is 
mathematically identical with that of finding the centre of gravity of 
two weights, and placing a weight equal to their sum at the point so found. 
We shall therefore speak of the resultant tint as <s>being placed at the centre
of gravity of its components<\s> the sum of its components placed at their centre 
of gravity.
